intro: Loranthus sarcophyllus, commonly known as the Australian mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of its host trees, primarily eucalyptus species. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while also producing its own sugars through photosynthesis using the light it captures. The plant has small, oval-shaped leaves and produces small, white or yellowish flowers that are often visited by insects. Its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release tiny seeds, which are dispersed by birds. This species plays an important ecological role in its native habitat by supporting a variety of wildlife.
